speaker: Frasier
text: Danielle, you're going to have to slow down a little bit, I'm having a hard time understanding you.

speaker: Danielle
text: [_v.o.; strong French accent_] I'm sorry, Dr. Crane.  I'm having a big, big problem with my monsieur.

speaker: Frasier
text: Excuse me, with your what?

speaker: Danielle
text: My monsieur.

speaker: Frasier
text: Your mithyuer?  _Both he and Roz are perplexed.  Apparently, his knowledge of French begins and ends with wine bottle labels._

speaker: Danielle
text: Oui, my monsieur.  Every day...

speaker: Frasier
text: Is that your mother?

speaker: Danielle
text: No.  My monsieur.

speaker: Frasier
text: Your masseur?  Your Mercedes?

speaker: Danielle
text: Monsieur!  My monsieur!  You must help me.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well Danielle, I, I, um... the best advice I can give you is to umm... either confront your mithyuer, or um, work on your self-esteem.  Thank you for your call. [_hangs up_] This is Dr. Frasier Crane, saying go out and have a good night, Seattle. You deserve it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz!  Aren't you screening these calls?

speaker: Roz
text: Yeah.  But when you only have one, you get a little less particular.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_admiring Roz_] You look nice.

speaker: Roz
text: Yeah?  Well, I've got a date tonight.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, great... Why are you only wearing one heel?  Did you break it off?

speaker: Roz
text: No, I'm dating a sea-captain with a peg-leg and this makes it easier when we dance. [_then_] I broke it off in a sidewalk grate.

speaker: Frasier
text: Okay, so who is this guy?  Another one of those trendy young kids who's got three earrings and a ponytail, wearing a T-shirt under his sports coat?

speaker: Roz
text: Is he here?

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz!  Where do you meet these people?

speaker: Roz
text: For your information, this guy happens to be a very successful media consultant.  He graduated from Princeton, he has a house on Mercer Island and he owns a forty-foot sailboat.

speaker: Frasier
text: You met him on a bus, didn't you?

speaker: Roz
text: No.  Actually we shared a cab... Alright, he was driving it.

speaker: Niles
text: Hello, Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: Hi, Niles.  You remember Roz?

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, of course. [_shakes Roz by the hand_] What brings you here?

speaker: Roz
text: Just passing by and thought I'd stop in for a career.

speaker: Niles
text: Good luck. [_to Frasier_] Sorry I'm late, Frasier, but the entrance to your parking garage is blocked by a cab driver with a ponytail, scraping gum off his back seat.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_to Roz_] Madame, your chariot awaits. [_Roz exits_] Well, we better get going, Niles.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh actually, bad news on that score, Frasier.  I'm afraid the lecture's been cancelled.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh.  Well, I can't say I'm really disappointed.  I wasn't relishing the idea of three hours on "Right brain, Left brain synergy."

speaker: Niles
text: I'll have you know I trimmed that speech to two and a half hours and I opened with a really funny Al Gore joke.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, it's no use crying over spilt milk.  Now... we've got a free evening.  This sound like the perfect opportunity for a couple of guys on the loose to, ah... hit a sports bar, have a couple of brewskis, maybe take in a game or two.

speaker: Niles
text: Right.  What shall we do?

speaker: Frasier
text: Dinner?

speaker: Niles
text: Perfect.  No place fancy, I'm sure neither of us wants a heavy meal with lots of wine and expensive desserts.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, it's your turn to pay, isn't it?

speaker: Niles
text: You know me so well. [_they leave_] **NOT NOW... NOW!**  _Scene Two - A small restaurant (Anya's) Frasier and Niles are seated at a booth by the window.  The waitress gives them menus._

speaker: Niles
text: Thank you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you.

speaker: Niles
text: Are you sure it's all right to park in that lot across the street?  The sign says it was just for customers of those stores, I don't want to get a ticket.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, it's fine, Niles.

speaker: Niles
text: I mean, I could get just nip back to Crabtree & Evelyn and buy a bar of lavender soap, just to be safe. [_stands_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh Niles, Niles.  Sit down.  Lavender soap - for God's sake, you're a man, you'd look ridiculous.

speaker: Waitress
text: Can I get you a drink?

speaker: Frasier
text: Fuzzy Navel, blended nice and frothy, please.  And a... martini, Niles?

speaker: Niles
text: No thanks, I'm driving. [_he's still worried about his car_] Maybe I'll buy a bag of Potpourri, or a set of hand towels.

speaker: Frasier
text: Just sit down.

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier.  Unless my eyes deceive me, that's Dad sitting over there.

speaker: Frasier
text: God, you're right.  Gee, that's strange, he said he was going over to Duke's to have a beer with a couple of the boys.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, that certainly isn't the boys.  Seems we've caught him in a clandestine rendezvous.

speaker: Frasier
text: The sly boots.  He had a date, and he didn't want us to know.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, he's looking this way, turn around, turn around!

speaker: Frasier
text: What are they doing?

speaker: Niles
text: [_peeking_] Well, it's sort of cute.  He's holding her hand. [_Frasier risks a peek_] Don't look, don't look.  I'll tell you when you can look.  Not now... Not now... Okay, now. [_Frasier looks_] No, not now! [_Frasier hides again_] Oh, I don't like this one bit.

speaker: Frasier
text: Why, what are they doing now?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh nothing, I just realized if Dad's eating here this can't be a very good restaurant.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, I wonder if it's their first date?

speaker: Niles
text: Well, if it is, they seem to be having a very good time.

speaker: Frasier
text: Why, what are they doing?

speaker: Niles
text: Well, they're leaning in and talking to each other.  He's smiling at her, she's... just collapsed in tears, she's sobbing uncontrollably.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, yeah.  That's a Crane first date all right.

speaker: Niles
text: She's coming this way, hide. [_the woman passes their table_] Frasier, do you know who that is?

speaker: Frasier
text: She did look familiar.

speaker: Niles
text: I'd swear that was Marion Lawler.

speaker: Frasier
text: Marion Lawler?  My God, I haven't heard that name since I was a kid.

speaker: Niles
text: I thought Mom and Dad had a huge falling-out with the Lawlers.

speaker: Frasier
text: They did, they did.  It was that last summer we shared a cabin with them at the lake.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, maybe Dad's getting together just to patch things up.

speaker: Frasier
text: And doing his usual bang-up job.

speaker: Niles
text: This is really awkward.  We should just get out of here.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, Niles.  If we leave now, he's sure to spot us. [_looks out the window_] You know, Niles, maybe you should have that martini after all.

speaker: Niles
text: I can't drink, Frasier.  I'm driving.

speaker: Frasier
text: Not anymore, they just towed your car. _Niles nods, then starts and looks out the window.  He buries his head.  FADE TO:_ **THE LADY VANISHES**  _Scene Three - Frasier's Apartment. Eddie is having a good roll around on the sofa. Daphne enters._

speaker: Daphne
text: Eddie, you little hooligan.  Get off that couch.  You know you're not supposed to do that.  If Dr. Crane sees you, he's going to throw you off the balcony and I'll be right behind you. [_puts Eddie on the floor_] Good boy.  Now just stay there.  _As soon as she leaves, Eddie jumps back up and starts rolling again. Frasier enters.  Eddie immediately sits on the floor before Frasier sees him._

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, Eddie. Glad to see my rules about the couch are finally taking hold.

speaker: Frasier
text: Good dog. [_shouts_] Dad?  Daphne?

speaker: Daphne
text: [_entering_] Oh, hello Dr. Crane.

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello, Daphne.  Say, where's Dad?

speaker: Daphne
text: Mr. Dawcy down on eight invited him over to watch the ball game.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, great.  He's finally getting to know some of the neighbors.

speaker: Frasier
text: What are you staring at?

speaker: Daphne
text: Have you ever thought about growing a moustache?

speaker: Frasier
text: No, I don't think it would suit me.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, yes it does.

speaker: Frasier
text: You've never seen me with one.

speaker: Daphne
text: Actually, I have.  There's a billboard for your show down on Sixteenth Street.  Some kids went at you with a can of spray paint.

speaker: Frasier
text: And it looked good?

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, yes.  But a word to the wise - take good care of your teeth. That look is not at all flattering on you. [_the doorbell rings_] I'll get it. [_she opens the door for Niles_] Hello, Dr. Crane.

speaker: Niles
text: Hello, Daphne.

speaker: Daphne
text: What brings you here?

speaker: Niles
text: A rental car, thanks to my brother.

speaker: Frasier
text: I assume you're here for a reason?

speaker: Niles
text: Ah, yes.  Frasier, last night when I got home, that strange incident with Dad and Mrs. Lawler got me to thinking, what was it that caused the rift between our two families?  So, I dug out my old boyhood journal, [_produces it_] and looked up my entries from our last summer together at the lake.  According to this, there was a three-week period where Mom and Dad had screaming matches every night, after we went to bed.

speaker: Frasier
text: I don't recall that.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, that's right.  That was the same period where you insisted on wearing the wax earplugs and the slumber mask.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I had to, what with you underneath the covers with a flashlight looking at the _National Geographic._

speaker: Niles
text: I was looking at the maps.

speaker: Frasier
text: That's what makes it so scary.  Now what was your point?

speaker: Niles
text: Well, according to my journal, something more provocative happened during that same period.  Here, read this. [_hands over book_]

speaker: Frasier
text: [_reading_] "Though summer at the lake seems but a vapid, vacuous experience, it is a necessary tonic for my troubled youth..." Niles, how old were you when you wrote this?

speaker: Niles
text: Almost nine.  Which explains the redundancy -- "Vapid" and "Vacuous."

speaker: Frasier
text: Well...

speaker: Niles
text: By ten, my writing had gotten considerably tighter.

speaker: Frasier
text: Amongst other things.

speaker: Niles
text: The point is, that same night I crept out onto the screen porch, leaving the lights off so not to attract bats and moths.  As I peered out through the darkness, between the trees I saw the figures of Dad and Mrs. Lawler in each other's arms.  I think it's pretty clear what happened, Frasier.  Dad and Mrs. Lawler had an affair.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, come on, Niles.  Look, I appreciate your attempt to spice up our family history, but really - look, we're not a Jackie Collins novel, it's ridiculous.

speaker: Niles
text: Is it?  All right, allow me to present Exhibit B.  This is a photo album Mom prepared of photos from the same period.  _Daphne enters, and comes over to look.  Niles takes a quick sniff of her hair._

speaker: Daphne
text: Ooh, I love to see old family photos. [_looks_] My goodness-- what a handsome, sinewy young bloke.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yeah, that was our dad.

speaker: Daphne
text: You two take after your mother, don't you?

speaker: Niles
text: All right, all right, look at this picture.  And this one here. That's Dad, but the person next to him has been cut out.  And, if you look at this one you can still see the edges of a dress and a handbag and tan sandals.

speaker: Daphne
text: Here's one whose head should have been cut out.  That scrawny little chap with the fish-belly complexion and rain hat.

speaker: Niles
text: [_for it is he_] I was under doctor's orders to stay out of direct sunlight.

speaker: Frasier
text: Look, we don't know for sure if that was Mrs. Lawler.  And besides, even then it wouldn't prove that Dad had an affair with her.

speaker: Daphne
text: What are you two talking about?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Niles has this theory that Dad had an illicit affair when we were youngsters.

speaker: Daphne
text: Your father?  I can't believe that, he's not the type.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, that's what I think.  Besides Niles, there's not enough proof.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, are you saying it's not possible?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, anything is possible.

speaker: Daphne
text: Then why don't you just ask him?

speaker: Frasier
text: Right.  "Good evening, father.  By the way, did you boff one of the neighbors while we were roasting marshmallows?"

speaker: Niles
text: Ah, ah.  There's one sure way to get the truth.  We'll call Aunt Vivian. [_goes to phone_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, no.

speaker: Daphne
text: Who's Aunt Vivian?

speaker: Niles
text: Better known as The Mouth.  Keeper of the Crane family skeletons.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_takes phone from Niles_] No, Niles, we are not calling Aunt Vivian.

speaker: Niles
text: Why?  Are you scared you'll find out something you don't want to know?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes.  That she knows where I live and that she still drives.

speaker: Daphne
text: You two are worse than a couple old washerwomen gossiping over a back fence.  I'm telling you, the way to sort this is to ask your father.

speaker: Martin
text: Ask me what?

speaker: Daphne
text: Your sons here have some cock-eyed notion that you had an affair with some woman thirty years ago.

speaker: Martin
text: What? [_both Niles and Frasier hang their heads in shame_] Where the hell'd that idea come from?

speaker: Niles
text: Well, last night... Frasier saw you having dinner with Marion Lawler.

speaker: Frasier
text: You were with me!

speaker: Martin
text: So what were you doing, spying on me?

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no Dad, we were just having dinner together - at the same time when you were supposed to be having some drinks with your buddies at Duke's.

speaker: Martin
text: And that proves I had an affair thirty years ago?

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no.  But Niles dug out his journal and then he remembered this time when he saw you and her hugging, and it was right around the same time when you and Mom seemed to be fighting a lot.

speaker: Niles
text: And then you suddenly stopped seeing the Lawlers.

speaker: Martin
text: I don't believe this, this is stupid.

speaker: Daphne
text: That's what I told them.  The hens here were even going to give some Aunt Vivian person a call.

speaker: Martin
text: Ah... Daphne, would you give me a minute alone with these two?

speaker: Daphne
text: Of course.  I completely understand. [_under her breath, as she leaves_] That's right, send the help to her room.  I never get to hear any of the good stuff anyway.

speaker: Martin
text: Look, don't bother calling Aunt Vivian.  You want to know the truth?  Fine.  I had an affair.  It happened a long time ago and  it's not anything I'm proud of.  And now that I've answered all your questions, do me a favor.  This is never to be brought up again, understand?  End of discussion.

speaker: Niles
text: Well... it's times like this that most families pull together and draw strength from each other. [_beat_] What shall we do?  _END OF ACT ONE (Time: 12:20)  ACT TWO_  **DR. SHECKY CRANE**  _Scene Four - Cafe Nervosa. The waiter has just brought Frasier his coffee when Niles enters._

speaker: Frasier
text: [_to waiter_] Oh, thank you.

speaker: Niles
text: [_sitting_] Good, you're here.  I came by to see how you're doing, but I only have a few minutes.  I start my "Healing with Humor" support group tonight, and I still have to pick up my big shoes.

speaker: Frasier
text: How am I doing?  How are you doing, Niles?  Doesn't it bother you that your father cheated on my mother?

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier, your loyalties are seeping through, and I might point out that I got Mom's small features, while you got Dad's chunky thighs.

speaker: Frasier
text: The point is, that it must have caused Mom a great deal of pain.

speaker: Niles
text: Agreed, but they went on and had a very happy life together. They got over it.  Why can't you?

speaker: Frasier
text: I know that rationally I should be able to handle this.  I deal with people who exemplify human frailty every day.  _Another customer starts browsing in the bookcase behind the brothers._

speaker: Frasier
text: But in this case it's not people, is it?  One of our parents had an illicit affair. [_the man's ears prick up at this_] How could he cheat with Marion, knowing the effect it would have on Mom, not to mention the repercussions it would have on you and me later on... [_to man_] Why don't you just pull up a chair and join us?

speaker: Frasier
text: I just can't believe that it's our father.  You know, I never had a great relationship with him.  But if there was one thing I always respected about him, it was his integrity.  Just thinking about what they did, it just sickens me.

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier, as your brother, as a therapist, I think you have to let this go.  And a good first step would be to come with me to my "Healing with Humor" support group.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you Niles, but I think I just need a night to myself.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, if you change your mind it should be a hoot.  As we speak, I'm wearing oversized polka-dot boxers and quick-release suspenders. [_N.B. This brings to mind an episode of "Cheers" where Frasier was forced to fill in for Woody as a clown at a birthday party, which ended with a faux pas involving quick-release suspenders, the birthday boy's grandmother, and a set of French thong underpants that Lilith bought him on a whim. -- Mike Lee_]   **THINGS BEST LEFT UNSAID**  _Scene Five - Frasier's Apartment. Eddie is rolling on the sofa again, but this time Frasier enters and catches him._

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I see all sorts of things have been going on behind my back!

speaker: Marion
text: Frasier?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_coldly_] Yes.

speaker: Marion
text: You may not remember me.  Marion Lawler.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, I remember you. [_they shake hands_]

speaker: Marion
text: Is your dad home?

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah, no.  but if you come back later you can have the place to yourselves.

speaker: Marion
text: No, that's not necessary.  I had dinner with him the other night, and I left rather abruptly.  I just wanted to tell him I'm sorry.  Would you please give him my best?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I think you've already done that.

speaker: Marion
text: Did I come at a bad time?  You seem upset.

speaker: Frasier
text: Would you come in for a moment, please? [_she enters_] After you met with Dad the other night, ah, he and I had a little conversation.  That was the first time I learned what happened that summer.

speaker: Marion
text: Oh, I'm sorry.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well... I guess I'm not the sort of person who can hear news like that and just sweep it under the rug and forget about it.

speaker: Marion
text: I know you're upset.  But if it's any consolation, in time your father and I forgave them.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_suddenly realizing_] Forgave _them_?

speaker: Marion
text: Frasier, your mother was a good person.  So was my husband. They made a mistake.  Anyway, just tell your father I stopped by.  I felt so silly crying in front of him the other night. I've been a little overemotional since Dan died.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I'm sorry, I didn't know.

speaker: Marion
text: Well, you never know how hard that's going to hit you.  Look who I'm telling this to - the famous radio psychiatrist, Dr. Frasier Crane.  I remember you when you used to run around in your undies with your pail and shovel.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, well I rarely get to the shore anymore.

speaker: Marion
text: Well... goodbye, Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: Goodbye.  _Marion leaves.  Frasier closes the door, looking heartsick.  FADE TO:_  **LIKE FATHER, LIKE SON**  _Scene Six - Frasier's Apartment. Martin is on his back, doing his exercises, while Daphne flexes his leg._

speaker: Daphne
text: Working down at the docks has always been a tradition for us Moons.  My father worked on the docks, and me grandfather before him.  All my brothers do.  Well, except for my brother Billy. He came home one day, and announced he hated the smell of fish and was going to teach ballroom dancing.  And he did.  And he does.  He's my mum's favorite.  Dad mostly flicks the crust off his kidney pie at him.

speaker: Martin
text: How much longer do I have to do this?

speaker: Daphne
text: Be patient.  You don't want to go through life dragging your leg behind you like a dead tree branch.

speaker: Martin
text: I'm talking about listening to your family's history.

speaker: Daphne
text: Now, I know you don't mean that.  Why would a man of your intelligence say a thing like that when you're in the position you're in- [_flexes his leg_] and I'm in the position I'm in?

speaker: Martin
text: All right, all right!

speaker: Daphne
text: Up you come. [_helps Martin to stand_] That's much better. I'll go run your bath.

speaker: Frasier
text: Hi, Dad.  You look kinda tired.

speaker: Martin
text: [_settling into chair, turning on TV_] Yeah.  Just finished my exercises with Nurse Ratchet.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah, listen Dad, do you have to watch the TV right now?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, my program's on.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, you know, if either of us could work the VCR, we'd tape it.  But, ah, just for now there's something I'd like to talk to you about. [_turns off TV_]

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, for God's sake, Frasier.  I know what this is, I've already told you everything I'm going to.  Now drop it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad.  Why didn't you tell me the truth?

speaker: Martin
text: I did.

speaker: Frasier
text: Marion Lawler came by today.  She wanted to apologize for the other night.  While she was here, she... she told me what really happened.

speaker: Martin
text: Alright, so now you know.  You did your little digging, and you stuck your nose in where it didn't belong, are you happy now?

speaker: Frasier
text: Why didn't you tell me it was Mom?

speaker: Martin
text: Because it's none of your damn business, and it still isn't.

speaker: Frasier
text: Look dad, I don't blame you for being defensive, but I had a right to know.  For your information, this sort of thing happens to a lot of people.  If it's any consolation, I know exactly how you feel.  I never told you this but, um... Lilith did the same thing to me.

speaker: Martin
text: Lilith had an affair?

speaker: Frasier
text: The most painful and humiliating experience of my entire life. Well, I'm sure you felt the same way.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I hadn't thought about it for quite some time, but thanks for reminding me. [_starts laughing_] Lilith?

speaker: Frasier
text: I found her attractive.  I mean, is it so inconceivable that another man might find her attractive as well?

speaker: Martin
text: [_not convinced_] I guess.  So who was the bozo in your case?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, God.  A Frenchman who lived in a self-contained underground eco-pod.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, that still sounds better than a urologist with a bad comb-over.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm sorry, dad.

speaker: Martin
text: Look son, do me a favor.  Don't hate your mother for this. I wasn't the easiest person to live with back then, and she had plenty of reason to do what she did.  Luckily we were able to put it behind us, but I'll tell you... there were times when it really tore me up.  I loved your mother.

speaker: Frasier
text: So did I.

speaker: Martin
text: I'm sorry.  That's why I said I was the one who had the affair. I was just trying to protect her.  Hey, me you already had problems with.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well dad, I appreciate what you did, but ah, I still think you should have told me.

speaker: Martin
text: Listen.  When Frederick grows up, will you tell him what Lilith did to you?

speaker: Martin
text: Okay.  Can I watch my program now?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, no.  Just one second. [_gets the photo album_] There's one thing I gotta clear up.  There's this photo album here, there's all these pictures with the same woman that's been cut out of them, you see this?

speaker: Martin
text: What else do you notice, Sherlock?  Like, where's your mother?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh.  Oh, that was mom?

speaker: Martin
text: She cut herself out of it.  She put a few pounds on that summer. I think that day she was wearing a brown dress with a belt, and your Aunt Vivian told her she looked like a knockwurst tied in the middle.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know dad, ever since you moved in we've been trying to find something that we have in common.  I think we've finally found it.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah... wish it was a birthmark.

speaker: Frasier
text: So do I. _Frasier goes to his room.  Martin turns on the TV.  End of Act Two (Time: 09:30)_
